Description: PRESETn must always be in a known state (aka: valid; either 0 or 1)
PSEL must always in a known state (aka: valid; either 0 or 1)

PENABLE must always be in a known state (valid; either 0 or 1) when PSEL is asserted in the same clock cycle
(more specifically; PENABLE = 0 indicates the begginig of the transaction & 
after one clock cycle PENABLE = 1 indicates the 2nd/subsequent cycle in the transaction)
PADDR is in a known state (valid) when PSEL is active (control signal)
PWRITE is in a known state (valid) when PSEL is active (control signal)
If PSEL signal is at a logic 1 and PWRITE is at logic 1, then PWDATA must be valid
If PSEL signal is at a logic 1 and PWRITE is at logic 1, then PSTRB must be valid
If PENABLE is active then PREADY is in a known state (valid)
If PENABLE is active then PSLVERR is in a known state (valid)

If PENABLE is at logic 1 && PWRITE is at logic 0 && PREADY is at logic 1,
then PRDATA is valid
PENABLE is de-asserted once PREADY becomes active
There is only one clock delay between PSEL and PENABLE
When PSEL becomes active, the PADDR, PWRITE, PWDATA, PSTRB

Signal Name: Functional Coverage (Dual Port Memory Slave Specific)

Description: Cover how many times PRESETn was equal to 1 & 0 over the transactions generated
Cover how many address was hit over 1000 transaction
Cover how many times PWRITE was equal to 1 & 0 over the transactions generated
Cover how many times PSTRB # of bits was equal to 0, 1, 2, 3 over the transactions generated
Cover how many times PSLVERR was equal to 1 & 0 over the transactions generated
Cross Coverage PWRITE and PADDR
Cross Coverage PWRITE and PSTRB
